No, no, let him bite on the bridle.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: But, Sir Wilful—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: No entreating, Sir John. It is only waſte of breath. It will be to no purpoſe. Here has been a pretty lady from London, this month paſt interceding for him. If ſhe can do any thing with him, well and good; otherwiſe I am inexorable. Not but that he ſhall have all when I die; I'll not give ſixpence out of the family—But not a farthing more than his allowance while I live. But I ſhall ſurvive the rogue; he'll certainly come to be hanged. I have heard ſuch things of him! he'll certainly come to be hanged.

div.stage: Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The coach is returned, Sir, with the ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Gadſo, ay, ſhew them up.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Ladies! Sir Wilful.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Only a neighbour or two, juſt to make up a party for a country dance after dinner. Sir Wilful goes, to the door, to introduce the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Manl.
sp.p: [Aſide.] This queer old Baronet is ſo troubleſome with his civility, I find I muſt go through the impertinence of a public wedding after all.

div.stage: Enter Lady Lucy, elegantly dreſſed:

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: [Leading Lady Lucy forward.] Sir John Manly.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: So! I muſt ſalute them too, it ſeems. [He goes to ſalute Lady Lucy, and ſtarts back.] My love! my dear! Is it you? Why this change of dreſs? Wherefore thus metamorphoſed?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I hope my features are not alter'd with my clothes.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: No, my love; but you can receive no addition by dreſs that will not injure the ſimplicity of your charms.

lg.l: Can ſhreds of ſattin, ſilk or lace
By mode or taſte combin'd,
Beſtow one beauty in the face,
One virtue on the mind?
Then, Flora, wherefore ſtoop ſo low
To have recourſe to art?
Your charms require not dreſs nor ſhew,
To captivate the heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: All this is very true, Sir John. But hereby hangs a tale. It was formerly an odd cuſtom for the Lord of this Manor—

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Why are not you he?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Not I, Sir: no, no. The preſent Lord is a relation of mine by marriage. I thought you had known him; but you'll know him preſently.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Well, Sir; and what of him?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Being a humoriſt and a man of pleaſure, he lately took it into his head to revive the obſolete cuſtom, I was going to tell you of; by promiſing a handſome marriage portion to a tenant's daughter, on condition of her indulging him in the privilege of a huſband on her wedding-night.

sp.speaker: Many.
sp.p: And ſhe has found a man, I ſupppſe, that will marry her on ſuch conditions!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Our peaſantry, Sir John, are few of them ſo nice as to let honour ſtand in the way of profit.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: But what is all this to us, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: True, Sir John, that is as you take it; but the point is, your ſpouſe is the damſel, on whom my kinſman has promiſed to beſtow his bounty, and as he is ready to fulfil his part of the agreement, he thinks he has a right to inſiſt on the performance of covenants on the part of the bride.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I ſee you are diſpoſed to be merry with me, Sir Wilful.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Gadſo, but I am very ſerious, Sir John. The maiden, never dreaming it would be her lot to meet with a huſband, who ſhould object to the condition of the obligation, thought there was no harm in thus providing herſelf with ſomething to begin the world with. But, if you refuſe your conſent, to be ſure, the landlord muſt forego his claim.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Conſent! Confound his claim and his covenant too! I'll ſhoot him through the head, for having the inſolence to mention it.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: And me through the heart at the ſame time, Sir?

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Since all muſt come out, Sir, it is in vain to deny that I love this landlord.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Love him! Sir Wilful's kinſman! the lord of the manor!

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: The ſame, Sir.

lg.l: Let lord and huſband have his due;
I yield to each his part;
For when I gave my hand to you,
I gave to him my heart.
While your commands I, then, obey,
And prove a loving wife;
O'er him, Oh! let me bear the ſway,
A miſtreſs, lov'd for life.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Mighty loving, indeed! I thank you for your love, Madam. —But what can you ſee in me ſo abſurd as to attempt thus to impoſe upon me?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Take care you don't impoſe on yourſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Madam! who is this landlord? — Let me ſee him. What's his name? Where is he?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: If you can command your paſſion, Sir, you may find, yourſelf alone with him in the adjoining gallery, and be ſatisfied of his claim.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam, he ſhall give me ſatisfaction, depend on it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Egad, his blood circulates purely. What a confounded flurry he is in!

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I begin to pity him, Sir; he ſuffers too much from an imaginary evil. Let us follow him. Exeunt.

div.stage: SCENE, Another Apartment in the Manor-houſe.
Enter Sir John Manly in great agitation.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Confuſion! What can I make of all this? [Looking anxiouſly about.] I ſee nobody.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Townly, in man's cloaths.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Ah, ha! here he comes. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: [Aſide.] So far, ſo good. Now, if I can but ſteal undiſcovered to her dreſſing-room— Walks on tip-toe acroſs the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: [Coming forward and ſtopping her.] Yes, Sir; but you don't ſteal undiſcovered to her dreſſing-room, I aſſure you,. 'Sdeath, Sir! how dare you have the impudence to think a gentleman would ſuffer ſuch an inſult? Draw this moment, or— Drawing his ſword.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: You know very well what's the matter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: The deuce take me, if I do.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Come, come, draw, my little rampant lord land'ord.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: Landlord: The deuce a landlord am I, Sir. Not a manſion, hovel, or tenement have I in the whole county—Nay, Sir, I am only tenant at will to the cloaths on my back.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: It is in vain to trifle. You were ſneaking to her dreſſing-room. Draw, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: Not I, Sir, without ſome better reaſon.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Doſt thou talk of reaſon too, thou contemptible little animal?

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Town. Yes, faith, do I. And I think it very hard, for a man who has juſt fallen in one duel, to be taken up ſo ſoon by a ſecond.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Do you laugh at me, Sir? Advancing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir! I tell you I have been ſhot once to-day already. You would not go to kill me again.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Inſolent trifler! —Defend yourſelf this moment, or, by heavens— Puts himſelf in a poſture of defence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: Nay, then, it is well I ſecured my firearms. Aſide.

lg.l: The man is ſtark mad without doubt!
And this for my ſafety expedient— Preſents a piſtol to Manly, who retires.
To the right, if you pleaſe—Wheel about—
'Tis well, Sir—So—There—Your obedient. Croſſes the ſtage, and exit.

div.stage: Manet Manly, with his ſword drawn, in great confuſion.
Sir Wilful and Lady Lucy enter at folding doors that open in the centre of the ſcene.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! What, fencing with the air, man? Fighting with your own ſhadow?

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: It is well, Sir, that your age and houſe protect you. As for you, Madam, I have learned to deſpiſe you, ſince I have ſeen the thing on which you had placed your affections.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: What thing, Sir?

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: That toy of ſilk and tinſel, that went out juſt now. Bullies ſhould be made of more ſubſtantial ſtuff. But, thank Heaven, our marriage is not conſummated, nor ever ſhall. I'll ſue out a divorce, or ride poſt to Japan, but I'll get rid of this affair.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: [to Lady Lucy.] Codſo! We ſhall carry this joke too far here: the man's brain is turned in good earneſt.— [To Manly.] Why, Sir John, there was nobody here but in your own imagination.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Away! thou egregious old coxcomb. Putting up his ſword and going.

lg.l: Oh, ſtay! Ah, turn, my only dear!
The ſportive trial's too ſevere;
It pains me thus to grieve you.
Leave not in rage your faithful bride.
But lay your fears and frowns aſide,
And let her undeceive you.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Madam! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I mean, Sir, that you yourſelf are the favourite landlord in queſtion. It is you who gave me the promiſe of your whole fortune for my wedding-portion. —It is you to whom I have given both my hand and heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: It is even ſo, Sir John. This is my niece Lucy, late Lady of the Manor; and you my new kinſman, who have entered, it ſeems, into a matrimonial contract to go to bed together. You ſee you have ſtumbled on a fortune without knowing it.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and I now give you my portion in poſſeſſion, in return for yours in promiſe. —This morning I was miſtreſs of this manſion, with all the paſtures and plowed fields within two miles round. At preſent they are yours: you are their owner now, lord of this manor and me.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Oh, yes, it is very poſſible that things ſhould be as they are. Well, Sir John, what ſay you now? Shall the marriage be conſummated or not? Shall the landlord have his due? or will you ſhoot him through the head? Sue out a divorce, or ride poſt to Japan, to get rid of this affair? Hah?

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: I am dumb with admiration.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I was reſolved, Sir, never to venture on a huſband, till I was convinced that my perſon, rarather than my fortune, was his aim. —That proof you have generouſly given me; and I am rejoiced that I can make you this grateful return. —You muſt impute the artifices, I have uſed in procuring this aſſurance, to the deſign concerted between you and your friend, for the diſpoſal of both my perſon and fortune without my conſent.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: I own it; with bluſhes I own it. How ſhall I repay thy generoſity? —Give me thy hand, thy lips, thy heart; there let me dwell, and be for ever happy. Embraces her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There, there; ſo, ſo. All's compos'd again. Egad, I was afraid you were non compos, when you talked of meeting a bully here.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: By heavens, I encountered an inſolent boy, who with fire arms ſet me at defiance and retired.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Mrs. Townly, as I live, returning from her expedition againſt Mr. Wildman; who is in conſequence, you ſee, taken into cuſtody. You muſt join with us in inflicting a little imaginary puniſhment too on your friend.

div.stage: Enter Wildman, guarded by a Conſtable and other country fellows: with Farmer Sternold, who goes up to Lady Lucy and converſes with her aſide.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: [To Sir Wilful.] An pleaſe your worſhip, we have apprehended a vagrom here, who has committed a murder, as I may ſay, in Farmer Sternold's cloſe. And ſo we have brought him to take his examination afore your worſhip, and be committed to gaol.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Murder! ſay you? Whom has he murdered?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p:
Nea, nea, I did na ſee the dead mon, to be ſure, to aſk'un. But the fellow and he, beliken, had
ſome words about their ſweethearts, and ſo he ſhot'un that's aw.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [To Wildman.] I always told you, George, what theſe wild doings would bring you to; but you would ſtill run riot upon every thing. What could you expect?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, faith, we have made a very fine expedition of it. One of us is married to a jilt, and the other will be hanged for killing her bully.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: A fair confeſſion. Where's John, clerk! Here, let him make out the fellow's mittimus. I'll diſpatch him to the county jail, in an inſtant.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To the county jail! Sir John, you will be bound for my appearance at the aſſizes.

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: As to that, George, I muſt beg to be excuſed. I am ſorry for you, but a murder is ſerious affair, and the law muſt take its courſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Ay, certainly—Where's John, clerk! The vagrant ſtands committed.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Then, Sir, for the ſake of your family, I muſt be ſo free as to acquaint you who I am. Look at me, Sir, are my features unknown to you?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Gadſo! Where's my ſpectacles! Let me ſee—Ay, ſure enongh, the very fellow that I committed to Lincoln jail for horſe-ſtealing! Egad, friend, if yours be a family phiz, it is a very unpromiſing one, I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And yet, Sir, I am your nephew, George Wildman.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: My nephew! you George Wildman!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Tis too true, Sir Wilful, and I cannot help reflecting on the ſagacity of your late prediction. The young gentleman will certainly come to be hanged, as you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: True, but I did not think I ſhould have the trouble of ſigning his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p:
With your worſhip's leave; as the culprit
proves to be a kinſman of yours, and I am the only witneſs that can convict him; if he ſhould chuſe to ſupply the place of the poor girl's ſweetheart he has killed, and marry her, my evidence, you know, on that condition—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, thou raſcally old pandar.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Nay, no abuſe, friend; you have your choice. It is a fair offer; the girl or the gallows.

lg.l: Does the fooliſh fellow faulter?
Pr'ythee make no more delay;
Take the wench or take the halter,
Stand not ſhill-I, ſhall-I, pray.
While there's life, man, there is hope,
Take the wife and leave the rope.

sp.speaker: LADY LUCY.
sp.l: Sarce can I refrain from laughter.

lg.l: Mayn't the man be hang'd hereafter,
When to wife and huſband too—

sp.speaker: STERNOLD.
sp.l: The rope may prove a friend—

sp.speaker: Sir WILFUL.
sp.p: That's true.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Townly, in man's cloathes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Townly.
sp.p: Hey day! What's the matter here! All appear ſurpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ha! my little bully alive.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Townly.
sp.p: My antagoniſt in cuſtody! I expected as much. You may releaſe him, gentlemen, as I am unhurt. My foot only ſlipped, and my friend, the farmer, here, took the alarm before I could recover myſelf.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let me embrace you, my little bravo. Runs to embrace Mrs, Townly, who retires.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Town.
sp.p: Nay no more rudeneſs, Sir, at your peril. My Uncle Sternold is here to protect me. Don't you know his niece. Laura, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How! Laura!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: [After conferring with Lady Lucy, aſide.] Very frolickſome truly all this! A pretty piece of work, you young folks have made of it here. But come, come, it is my turn to have a frolick now. Look you here Mr. Scapegrace, I dare ſay, tho' Mrs. Laura did not chuſe to be a miſtreſs, ſhe will have no objections to be made a wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Townly.
sp.p: Sir Wilful.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Silence, huſſy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Townly.
sp.p: But, Sir Wilful!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How, Sir! a farmer's daughter!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Ay, ſirrah, or you ſhall inherit no farm lands of mine. A farmer's daughter, booby! Why every woman is ſomebody's daughter. But you're out, you rogue, this is Mrs. Townly, Sir, a London lady of family and fortune.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Mrs. Townly! Nay then I am caught in a ſnare, I thought I had eſcaped. Folly, I ſee, makes one as blind as love; I ſhould elſe have ſooner recollected thoſe features I have ſo often admired. May I hope, Madam— To Mrs. Townly.

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Townly. Nay don't talk to me about your hopes, I know nothing of the matter. Sir Wilful ſeems to diſpoſe of us all as his property; but—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But what, huſſy? Come take her hand, boy, take her hand. If you can venture for once on a wife, I warrant ſhe'll venture twice on a huſband. Wildman takes Mrs Townly's hand and eagerly kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Townly.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir; no more. Sir Wilful ſeems poſitive, but—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Again! at your buts?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, couſin, pay ſome regard, for my ſake, to the haſty example before you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Which if they don't follow, adod, I'll make ſuch an example of them—

sp.speaker: Manly.
sp.p: Never fear, Sir Wilful. I'll be bound for my friend's appearance at the aſſizes now. At the ſame time, take notice, George, that however you, libertines, may affect to turn matrimony into ridicule, there is no laſting bliſs but in honourable love.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Right, Sir John: And here I ſee are our neighbours and tenants aſſembled to wiſh you joy on the occaſion. Let them all come in—you muſt know it is our ſheepſhearing time, and we muſt make a general holiday of it.

lg.l: Falſe and flattering is the kiſs
Of the fickle faithleſs miſs.
True and faithfully for life,
Loves a chaſte endearing wife.
Marriage might indeed have joys,
Youth ſo true to beauty.
Laughing girls and blooming boys,
Bleſſing love and duty.
Joy, then, to the wedded pair!
Joy unmix'd with ſorrow!
Hold you there—an hour of care
Muſt bid an heir good-morrow.
Joy, then, to the wedded pair!
Joy, unmix'd with ſorrow!
Till the birth-day hour of care,
Bid girl or boy good-morrow.
